title: 05_mdp_lp
text:
Introduction

MDPs are a classical formalization of sequential decision making.

Actions influence not just immediate rewards, but also subsequent states, and through those, future rewards.
They are meant to be a straightforward framing of the problem of learning from interaction to achieve a goal.

MDPs involve delayed reward and the need to trade off immediate and delayed reward.
We will estimate the value q*(s,a)q_\ast(s, a) of each action aa in each state ss,

or we estimate the value v*(s)v_\ast(s) of each state given optimal action selections.

These state-dependent quantities are essential to accurately assigning credit for long-term consequences to individual action selections.

title: 05_mdp_lp
text:
The Agent â€“ Environment Interface






The decision maker is called the agent or controller.
The thing it interacts with, everything outside the agent, is called the environment or plant.
These interact continually, the agent selecting actions (or control signal) and the environment responding to these control signals and presenting new situations to the agent.
The environment also gives rise to rewards, special numerical values that the agent seeks to maximize over time through its choice of actions.








The agent and environment interact at each of a sequence of discrete time steps, t=0,1,2,â€¦t = 0, 1, 2, \ldots.

At each time step tt, the agent receives some respresentation of the environmentâ€™s state, Stâˆˆğ’®S_t \in \mathcal{S}, and on that basis selects an action Atâˆˆğ’œ(s)A_t \in \mathcal{A}(s).
One time step later, in part as a consequence of its actions, the agent receives a numerical reward, Rt+1âˆˆâ„›âˆˆâ„R_{t+1} \in \mathcal{R} \in \mathbb{R} and finds itself in a new state, St+1S_{t+1}.

The MDP and agent together give rise to a trajectory that begins like this: S0,A0,S1,R1,A2,R2,S2,A2,R3,â€¦(1) S_0, A_0, S_1, R_1, A_2, R_2, S_2, A_2, R_3, \ldots  \qquad(1)












In a finite MDP, the sets of states, actions, and rewards
(ğ’®,ğ’œ,â„›)(\mathcal{S}, \mathcal{A}, \mathcal{R}) all have a finite number of elements.

In this case, the random variables RtR_t and StS_t have well defined discrete probability distributions dependent on the preceding state and action.

A_{t-1} = a\}  \qquad(2)

This function pp defines the dynamics of the MDP.

It specifies a probability distribution for each choice of ss and aa, i.e.,

This is called the Markov property.

The time steps can refer to arbitrary successive stages of decision making.
The actions can be low-level controls (e.g.Â voltages), or high-level decisions (e.g.Â have lunch, go to grad school).
They can be determined by low-level sensing (e.g.Â sensor readings) or they can be more high-level and abstract (e.g.Â symbolic descriptions of objects in a room).
States can be anything we can know that might be useful in making the decisions.

title: 05_mdp_lp
text:
The Agent â€“ Environment Interface



Rule of thumb



Anything that cannot be changed arbitrarily by the agent is considered to be outside of it and thus part of its environment.





Not everything in the environment is unknown to the agent.

For example, the agent often knows how its rewards are computed as a function of its actions and the states.
Reward computation is external to the agent because it defines the task facing the agent and thus is beyond its ability to change arbitrarily.

In fact, some agents know everything about how its environment.




MDP framework


Whatever the details of the sensory, memory, and control apparatus, and whatever objective one is trying to achieve, any problem of learning goal-directed behavior can be reduced to three signals passing back and forth between an agent and its environment:

one signal to represent the choices made by the agent (the actions),
one signal to represent the basis on which the choices are made (the states),
one signal to define the agentâ€™s goal (the rewards).

title: 05_mdp_lp
text:
Examples



Example 1 â€“ Bioreactor


Suppose we want to determine moment-by-moment temperatures and stirring rates for a bioreactor.

The actions might be target temperatures and target stirring rates that are passed to the lower-level control system,

The control system, in turn, will activate heating elements and motors to attain the targets.

The states could be the outputs of a thermocouple and other sensory readings
The rewards might be moment-by-moment measures of the rate at which the useful chemical is being produced by the bioreactor.







Example 2 â€“ Pick-and-Place Robot


Suppose we want to control the motion of a robot arm in a repetitive pick-and-place task.

The actions might be the voltages applied to each motor at each joint.
The states might be the latest readings of joint angles and velocities.
The reward might be +1+1 for each object successfully picked up and placed.

To encourage smooth movements, at each time step, a small, negative reward could be given as a function of the moment-to-moment jerkiness of the motion.








Homework


Devise three example tasks of your own that fit into the MDP framework, identifying for each states, actions, and rewards.

It has sensors for detecting cans, and an arm and gripper that can pick them up and place them in an onboard bin; it runs on a rechargable battery.
The robotâ€™s control system has components for

title: 05_mdp_lp
text:
Goals and Rewards

The agentâ€™s goal is to maximize the total amount of reward it receives; not the immediate reward, but the cumulative reward in the long run.




Reward Hypothesis


All of what we mean by goal and purposes can be well thought as the maximization of the expected value of the cumulative sum of a received scalar signal (called reward).




Formulating goals in terms of reward signals has proved to be flexible and widely applicable.




Examples









Task
Reward




Robot walking
++ve reward on each time step proportional to robotâ€™s forward motion


Escape from a maze
âˆ’1-1 reward for every time step that passes prior to escape


Playing chess
+1+1 for winning, âˆ’1-1 for losing, 00 for drawing







The reward signal is no the place to impart to the agent prior knowledge about how to achieve what we want it to do (better places: initial policy, iniial value function).

Otherwise the agent might find a way to achieve subgoals without achieving the real goal!

title: 05_mdp_lp
text:
Returns and Episodes

In general, we seek to maximize the expected return, where the return, denoted GtG_t, is defined as some specific function of the reward sequence.

Simplest (bit naÃ¯ve) case: Gtâ‰œRt+1+Rt+2+â‹¯+RT=âˆ‘k=t+1TRk,(7) G_t \triangleq R_{t+1} + R_{t+2} + \cdots + R_T = \sum_{k=t+1}^T R_k,   \qquad(7)
Discounted return: Gtâ‰œâˆ‘k=0âˆÎ³kRt+k+1=âˆ‘k=t+1TÎ³kâˆ’tâˆ’1Rk,0â‰¤Î³â‰¤1.(8) G_t \triangleq \sum_{k=0}^\infty \gamma^kR_{t+k+1} =
\sum_{k=t+1}^T \gamma^{k-t-1}R_k, \quad 0 \leq \gamma \leq 1.  \qquad(8)

The naÃ¯ve approach makes sense in applications in which there is a natural notion of a final time step (episodes).

Each episodes ends in a state called the terminal state.
In episodic tasks we sometimes need to distinguish the set of all nonterminal states, ğ’®\mathcal{S} from the set of all states plus the terminal state, ğ’®+\mathcal{S}^+.

If the task has no final time, or terminal state, then T=âˆT=\infty.

The naÃ¯ve return may easily become infinite. Hence we use the discounted return. Gt=Rt+1+Î³(Rt+2+Î³Rt+3+Î³2Rt+4+â‹¯)=Rt+1+Î³Gt+1.(9) G_t = R_{t+1} + \gamma(R_{t+2} + \gamma R_{t+3} + \gamma^2 R_{t+4} + \cdots)
= R_{t+1} + \gamma G_{t+1}.  \qquad(9)

title: 05_mdp_lp
text:
Example â€” Pole-Balancing



A failure is said to occur if the pole falls past a given angle from vertical or if the cart runs off the track.

The pole is reset to vertical after each failure.

This task could be treated as episodic, where the natural episodes are the repeated atempts to balance the pole.

The reward in this case would be +1+1 for every time step on which failure did not occur.
The return at each time would be the number of steps until failure.
Successful balancing forever would mean a return of infinity.









Objective: Apply forces to a cart moving along a track so as to keep a pole hinged to the cart from falling over.






Alternatively, we could treat pole-balancing as a continuing task, using discounting.

In his case the reward would be âˆ’1-1 on each failur and zero all other times.
The return at each time would the be related to âˆ’Î³Kâˆ’1-\gamma^{K-1}, where KK is the number of time steps before failure.

In either case, the return is maximized by keeping the pole balanced for as long as possible.

title: 05_mdp_lp
section: How good are a state and an action?
text:
How good are a state and an action?

The rewards the agent can expect to receive in the future depend on what actions it will take.
Value functions are defined with respect to paricular ways of acting, called policies.






Definition


A policy is a mapping from states o probabilities of selecting each possible action.

If the agent is following policy Ï€\pi at time tt, then Ï€(a|s)\pi(a|s) is the probability that At=aA_t = a given that St=sS_t = s.
Ï€(a|s)\pi(a|s) defines a probability distribution over aâˆˆğ’œ(s)a \in \mathcal{A}(s) for each sâˆˆğ’®s \in \mathcal{S}.








Definition (State-Value Function for Policy Ï€\pi)


The value function of a state ss under a policy Ï€\pi, denoted vÏ€(s)v_\pi(s), is the expected return when starting in ss and following Ï€\pi thereafter.
vÏ€(s)â‰œğ”¼Ï€[Gt|St=s]=ğ”¼Ï€[âˆ‘k=0âˆÎ³kRt+k+1|St=s],âˆ€sâˆˆğ’®.(10) 
\begin{align}
v_\pi(s) &\triangleq \mathbb{E}_\pi[G_t | S_t = s] \\ 
&= \mathbb{E}_\pi\left[\sum_{k=0}^\infty \gamma^k R_{t+k+1} | S_t = s \right],
\;\; \forall s \in \mathcal{S}.
\end{align}
 \qquad(10)

The value of the terminal state, if any, is always zero.









Definition (Action-Value Function for Policy Ï€\pi)


We define the value of taking action aa in state ss under a policy Ï€\pi, denoted qÏ€(s,a)q_\pi(s, a), as the expected return starting from ss, taking the action aa, and thereafter following policy Ï€\pi:
qÏ€(s,a)â‰œğ”¼Ï€[Gt|St=s,At=a]=ğ”¼Ï€[âˆ‘k=0âˆÎ³kRt+k+1|St=s,At=a].(11) 
\begin{align}
q_\pi(s, a) &\triangleq \mathbb{E}_\pi[G_t | S_t=s, A_t=a] \\
&= \mathbb{E}_\pi\left[\sum_{k=0}^\infty \left. \gamma^k R_{t+k+1}\right| S_t=s, 
A_t=a \right].
\end{align}
 \qquad(11)

text:
Bellman Equation



Fundamental property of Value Functions


Value functions saisfy recursive relationships similar that which we established for the return EquationÂ 9.
For any policy Ï€\pi and any state ss, the following consistency condition holds between he value of ss and he value of its possible successor states:
vÏ€(s)â‰œ=ğ”¼Ï€[Gt|St=s]=ğ”¼Ï€[Rt+1+Î³Gt+1|St=s],by (9)=âˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œ(s)Ï€(a|s)âˆ‘sâ€²,rp(sâ€²,r|s,a)[r+Î³ğ”¼Ï€[Gt+1|St+1=sâ€²]]=âˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œ(s)Ï€(a|s)âˆ‘sâ€²,rp(sâ€²,r|s,a)[r+Î³vÏ€(sâ€²)],âˆ€sâˆˆğ’®.(12)
\begin{align}
v_\pi(s) \triangleq &= \mathbb{E}_\pi[G_t|S_t=s] = \mathbb{E}_\pi[R_{t+1} +
\gamma G_{t+1}|S_t = s], \quad {\text{by (9)} }\\
&= \sum_{a \in \mathcal{A}(s)} \pi(a|s)\sum_{s',r}p(s',r|s,a)\left[r + \gamma
\mathbb{E}_\pi[G_{t+1}|S_{t+1}=s']\right] \\
&= \sum_{a \in \mathcal{A}(s)} \pi(a|s) \sum_{s', r}p(s',r|s,a)\left[r + \gamma
v_\pi(s')\right],
\quad \forall s \in \mathcal{S}.
\end{align}
 \qquad(12)






Each open circle represents a state and each solid circle represents a state-action pair.
Starting from state ss, the root node at the top, the agent could take any of some set of actions â€” three are shown â€” based on its policy Ï€\pi.








From each of these, the environment could respond with one of several next states, sâ€²s' (two are shown), along with a reward, rr, depending on its dynamics, given by the function pp.
Bellman equation averages over all the possibilites, weighing each by its probability of occuring: the value of the start state must equal the (discounted) value of the expected next state, plus the reward expected along the way.

title: 05_mdp_lp
text:
Example â€” Gridworld





Gridworld is a finite Markov Decision Process.

The cells of the grid correspond to the states.
At each cell, four actions are possible: ğš—ğš˜ğš›ğšğš‘\texttt{north}, ğšœğš˜ğšğšğš‘\texttt{south}, ğšğšŠğšœğš\texttt{east}, ğš ğšğšœğš\texttt{west}
These actions deterministically cause the agent to move one cell in the respective direction of the grid.

Actions that would take the agent off the grid leave its location unchanged, but also incur a reward of âˆ’1-1.
Other actions reward 00, except those that move the agent out of the special states AA and BB.

From state AA, all four actions yield a reward of +10+10 and take the agent to Aâ€²A'.
From state BB, all actions yield a reward of +5+5 and take the agent to Bâ€²B'.





Exercise


The Bellman EquationÂ 12 must hold for each state for the value function vÏ€v_\pi. Show numerically that this equation holds for the center state, valued at +0.7+0.7, w.r.t. its four neighboring states, valued at +2.3+2.3, +0.4+0.4, âˆ’0.4-0.4, and +0.7+0.7 (accurate to one decimal place).






The agent selects all four actions with equal probability in all states.
Figure at the bottom shows the value function, vÏ€v_\pi, for this policy, for the discounted reward case with Î³=910\gamma = \frac{9}{10}.
Notice the negative values near the lower edge.

these are the results of the high probability of hitting the edge of the grid under the random policy.

State AA is the best state to be in under this policy.

Note: AAâ€™s expected return is less than its immediate reward of 1010 because from AA the agent is taken to state Aâ€²A' from which it is likely to run into the edge of the grid.

State BB, on the other hand, is valued more than its immediate reward of 55, because from BB the agent is taken to Bâ€²B' which has a positive value.

From Bâ€²B' the expected penalty (negative reward) for possibly running into an edge is more than compensated for by the expected gain for possibly stumbling onto AA or BB.

section: Optimal Policies and Optimal Value Functions
text:
Optimal Policies and Optimal Value Functions 

We want to find a policy that achieves a lot of reward over the long run.
Value functions define a partial ordering over policies: a policy Ï€\pi is defined to be better than or equal to a policy Ï€â€²\pi' if its expected return is greater than or equal to that of Ï€â€²\pi' for all states. Ï€â‰¥Ï€â€²â‡”vÏ€(s)â‰¥vÏ€â€²(s),âˆ€sâˆˆğ’®. \pi \geq \pi' \Longleftrightarrow v_{\pi}(s) \geq v_{\pi'}(s), \quad
\forall s \in \mathcal{S}. 
âˆƒ\exists always at least one policy that is better than or equal to all other policies: an optimal policy.

Although there may be more than one, let us denot all the optimal policies by Ï€*\pi_\ast.
They share the same state-value function, called the optimal state-value function:
v*(s)â‰œmaxÏ€vÏ€(s),âˆ€sâˆˆğ’®.(13) v_\ast(s) \triangleq \operatorname{max}_\pi v_{\pi}(s), \quad
\forall s \in \mathcal{S}.  \qquad(13)

Optimal policies also share the same optimal action-value function:
q*(s,a)â‰œmaxÏ€qÏ€(s,a),âˆ€sâˆˆğ’®,aâˆˆğ’œ(s).(14) q_\ast(s, a) \triangleq \operatorname{max}_\pi q_{\pi}(s, a), \quad
  \forall s \in \mathcal{S}, \; a \in \mathcal{A}(s).  \qquad(14)
For the state-action pair (s,a)(s,a), this function gives the expected return for taking action aa in state ss and thereafter following an optimal policy.

Thus, we can write q*q_\ast in terms of v*v_\ast as follows: q*(s,a)=ğ”¼[Rt+1+Î³v*(St+1)âˆ£St=s,At=a].(15) q_\ast (s, a) = \mathbb{E}[R_{t+1} + \gamma v_\ast(S_{t+1}) \mid S_t = s, A_t =
a].  \qquad(15)

title: 05_mdp_lp
text:
Bellman Optimality Equation

Because v*v_\ast is the value function for a policy, it must satisfy the self-consistency condition given by the Bellman equation for state values EquationÂ 12.
But it is also the optimal value function so v*v_\astâ€™s consistency condition can be written in a special form w/o reference to any specific policy!




The Bellman optimality equation expresses the fact that the value of a state under an optimal policy must equal the expected return for the best action from that state.



v*(s)=maxaâˆˆğ’œ(s)qÏ€*(s,a)=maxağ”¼Ï€*[Gt|St=s,At=a]=maxağ”¼Ï€*[Rt+1+Î³Gt+1|St=s,At=a]=maxağ”¼Ï€*[Rt+1+Î³v*(St+1)|St=s,At=a]=maxaâˆ‘sâ€²,rp(sâ€²,r|s,a)[r+Î³v*(sâ€²)].(16)
\begin{align}
v_\ast(s) &= \operatorname{max}_{a \in \mathcal{A}(s)} q_{\pi_\ast}(s, a) =
\operatorname{max}_{a} \mathbb{E}_{\pi_\ast}[G_t | S_t =s, A_t = a] \\
&= \operatorname{max}_a \mathbb{E}_{\pi_\ast}[R_{t+1} + \gamma G_{t+1} | S_t =
s, A_t = a] \\
&= \operatorname{max}_a \mathbb{E}_{\pi_\ast}[R_{t+1} + \gamma v_\ast(S_{t+1}) | S_t =
s, A_t = a] \\
&= \operatorname{max}_a \sum_{s', r} p(s', r|s, a)[r + \gamma v_\ast(s')].
\end{align}
 \qquad(16)

The Bellman optimality equation for q*q_\ast is

q*(s,a)=ğ”¼[Rt+1+Î³maxaâ€²q*(St+1,a)âˆ£St=s,At=a]=âˆ‘sâ€²,rp(sâ€²,r|s,a)[r+Î³maxaâ€²q*(sâ€²,aâ€²)].(17)
q_\ast(s, a) = \mathbb{E}\left[R_{t+1} + \gamma \operatorname{max}_{a'}
q_\ast(S_{t+1}, a) \mid S_t = s, A_t = a\right] = \sum_{s', r} p(s', r|s, a) 
\left[ r+ \gamma \operatorname{max}_{a'} q_\ast (s', a') \right].
 \qquad(17)

Linear Programming Methods





Short-hand notation
